sourcing.instructions: Cobalt (Co) - Available from chemical suppliers or online marketplaces. Iron (Fe) - Obtainable from metal suppliers or hardware stores. Zirconium (Zr) - Purchase from specialized metal suppliers or online chemical distributors.
steps: Cobalt (Co) - Available from chemical suppliers or online marketplaces. Iron (Fe) - Obtainable from metal suppliers or hardware stores. Zirconium (Zr) - Purchase from specialized metal suppliers or online chemical distributors.

1. Weigh out 255 g of cobalt powder, 102 g of iron powder, and 102 g of zirconium powder using a precision scale. 2. In a clean, dry mixing container, combine the three powders thoroughly using a mechanical mixer or mortar and pestle until a homogeneous mixture is achieved. 3. Ensure the mixture is free of clumps by sieving it through a fine mesh screen.
preparation.raw_text: 1. Weigh out 255 g of cobalt powder, 102 g of iron powder, and 102 g of zirconium powder using a precision scale. 2. In a clean, dry mixing container, combine the three powders thoroughly using a mechanical mixer or mortar and pestle until a homogeneous mixture is achieved. 3. Ensure the mixture is free of clumps by sieving it through a fine mesh screen.

steps: 1. Preheat a high-temperature furnace to 1,200 °C (2,192 °F). 2. Place the homogeneous powder mixture in a ceramic crucible suitable for high temperatures. 3. Insert the crucible into the preheated furnace and maintain the temperature for 2 hours to allow for solidification and alloying of the metals.
heating.raw_text: 1. Preheat a high-temperature furnace to 1,200 °C (2,192 °F). 2. Place the homogeneous powder mixture in a ceramic crucible suitable for high temperatures. 3. Insert the crucible into the preheated furnace and maintain the temperature for 2 hours to allow for solidification and alloying of the metals.

steps: 1. After the heating period, turn off the furnace and allow it to cool naturally to room temperature (approximately 25 °C or 77 °F). 2. Do not open the furnace until it has completely cooled to avoid thermal shock to the crucible.
cooling.raw_text: 1. After the heating period, turn off the furnace and allow it to cool naturally to room temperature (approximately 25 °C or 77 °F). 2. Do not open the furnace until it has completely cooled to avoid thermal shock to the crucible.

steps: 1. Once cooled, remove the crucible from the furnace and extract the solid alloy sample. 2. Use a diamond saw to cut the sample to the desired dimensions: 3 inches x 2 inches x 7 inches. 3. Sand the edges of the sample with fine-grit sandpaper to remove any sharp edges and achieve a smooth finish. 4. Optionally, apply a protective sealant to prevent oxidation and enhance the appearance.
post_processing.raw_text: 1. Once cooled, remove the crucible from the furnace and extract the solid alloy sample. 2. Use a diamond saw to cut the sample to the desired dimensions: 3 inches x 2 inches x 7 inches. 3. Sand the edges of the sample with fine-grit sandpaper to remove any sharp edges and achieve a smooth finish. 4. Optionally, apply a protective sealant to prevent oxidation and enhance the appearance.
